I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  A rapid switch to clean and efficient energy use is essential to reduce global greenhouse 
gas (GHG) emissions, ease the growth in fossil energy demand and upward pressure on energy 
prices, and ultimately improve energy security. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has a long-
standing commitment to increasing investment in energy efficiency and the use of clean and 
renewable energy in its developing member countries (DMCs) through its Strategy 20201 and its 
2009 Energy Policy.2 ADB has increasingly prioritized energy efficiency since 2007, and has 
expanded its investments by creating clean energy investment funds, such as the Clean Energy 
Financing Partnership Facility, and by providing technical assistance (TA) through projects such 
as Supporting the Implementation of the Energy Efficiency Initiative in Developing Member 
Countries and Expanding the Implementation of the Energy Efficiency Initiative in Developing 
Member Countries.3 ADB’s energy efficiency and clean energy portfolio has grown ahead of 
target from $668 million in 2007 to $2.36 billion in 2012.4 
2.  Demand-side energy efficiency (DSEE) is an approach to consume less energy for the 
same level of service at the end-use sectors, such as industrial, commercial and public sector, 
via  improved  efficiency  of  industrial  operations  and  appliances  etc.  However,  persistent 
obstacles, from economic, financial, to institutional, still need to be addressed to encourage 
further growth in DSEE investment. There is a strong rationale for ADB to build on its existing 
commitments by taking a more systematic approach to DSEE that emphasizes investment in 
strategic,  targeted,  and  replicable  DSEE  aggregation  projects,  and  is  backed  up  by  more 
sustainable DSEE technical capacity to assist both ADB operations departments and DMC 
governments. The proposed TA aims to establish this systematic approach to catalyzing DSEE 
projects.  The  TA  will  support  DSEE  project  initiatives  that  enhance  energy  security  and 
productivity, and limit the environmental impacts and carbon emissions that contribute to global 
climate change. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.5 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Energy use in DMCs is increasing rapidly to support the economic growth needed to 
raise the living standards of their large populations. Energy supply continues to be dominated by 
fossil fuel use, giving rise to an unsustainable energy future.6 While climate change is a global 
challenge, the poor will suffer most from its adverse impacts. The case for action is therefore 
particularly strong in Asia and the Pacific, which is home to more than half of the world’s poor. 
Without an order-of-magnitude increase in GHG mitigation investment, climate change impacts 
threaten to undermine the economic gains being made across the region. 
4.  Among  the  different  mitigation  investment  options,  DSEE  measures  (for  instance, 
efficient lighting, heating, ventilation, and air conditioning for buildings, efficient boilers, motors, 
compressors in industrial sector) stand out as the least-cost way to acquire new energy system

capacity and satisfy growing demand.7 To meet new energy demand, it is cheaper to create an 
additional unit of available energy by recovering it from existing energy waste than to generate it 
by any means.8 This is because it is less costly to deploy energy-efficient equipment and 
practices than to build new energy generation plant and account for energy loss in conversion, 
transmission, and distribution. DSEE also directly engages end-users of energy, and its profile 
is growing in many DMCs because of its effectiveness in enhancing energy security, addressing 
local power shortages, and contributing to climate change mitigation. Significant opportunities 
exist  for  economically  cost-effective  DSEE  investments,  notably  in  buildings,  industry, 
agriculture, and transport.9 
5.  The International Energy Agency  estimates that keeping global atmospheric carbon 
dioxide  concentrations  below  450  parts  per  million  by  2030  will  require  GHG  emissions 
mitigation investment in the order of $12 trillion, of which DSEE investments must account for 
over 60%.10 This expected contribution of DSEE to mitigation efforts clearly acknowledges its 
cost competitiveness and implementation readiness compared with other greenhouse mitigation 
options.  However,  current  investment  in  DSEE  remains  significantly  below  its  identified 
economic  potential  because  of  a  range  of  pervasive  barriers  that  hinder  scaled-up 
implementation. The International Energy Agency estimates that two-thirds of the economic 
potential to improve DSEE will remain untapped in the period to 2035; but if capitalized on, it 
could  delay  the  lock-in  of  global  carbon  dioxide  emissions  permitted  under  a  2-degrees-
centigrade trajectory—set to be reached in 2017—until 2022, buying 5 extra years (footnote 10).  
6.  Given the strong economic case that can often be made for DSEE, many DSEE projects 
and initiatives have been instigated and successfully implemented in the region. However, this 
has not translated directly into increased investment attraction, and DSEE projects have mostly 
remained small-scale, ad hoc, and opportunistic. Persistent barriers to DSEE investment have 
not yet been systematically removed. The following problems need to be addressed: 
(i)  Lack  of  capacity,  awareness,  and  orientation  toward  DSEE  projects. In 
many DMCs, there is low awareness of and demand for DSEE projects. The 
private energy savings industry in DMCs is often poorly developed, and public 
counterpart agencies, such as electric utilities, are oriented toward increasing 
energy  access  and  electrification,  rather  than  increasing  efficiency  through 
energy savings. Although DSEE potential may be recognized within the country, 
there is often no agency with the skills, authority, and mandate to design and put 
forward  DSEE  initiatives,  or  to  negotiate  substantial  DSEE  investments  with 
agencies such as ADB or commercial banks. 
(ii)  Lack of awareness and incentive structures for financiers. Compared to 
large-scale energy supply infrastructure, financiers generally feel uncomfortable 
with DSEE project risk due to the prevalence of non-collateral financing, the need 
to aggregate small loan amounts, the presence of multiple counterparties that 
require complex risk-sharing arrangements, the absence of guarantees, and the 
general  lack  of  expertise.  The  higher  transaction  costs  associated  with

7.  The proposed TA aims to address these shortcomings. While ADB is already a leader in 
investing in energy efficiency in Asia, and approximately 45% of its clean energy portfolio is 
classified as energy efficiency, it mostly undertakes supply-side investments (e.g., upgrading 
electricity transmission and distribution assets).11 The proposed TA will support ADB's goal of 
scaling-up and improving the effectiveness of its DSEE investment, and will increase the share 
of  DSEE  in  ADB’s  energy  portfolio.  It  will  build  on  work  completed  under  the  Technical 
Assistance for Expanding the Implementation of the Energy Efficiency Initiative in Developing 
Member Countries12, and will increase DMC capacity to extend its outcomes further. It will also 
address the findings of the 2011 Independent Evaluation Department report on enhancing the 
effectiveness of ADB’s energy efficiency interventions. 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The overall impact of the TA will be reduced GHG emissions and improved economic 
productivity through increased adoption of and investment in DSEE in DMCs. 
9.  The expected outcome will be that, through increased institutional capacity, greater 
access to information, and targeted TA, selected DMCs are able to facilitate increased DSEE 
investment and deployment, and better adopt DSEE targets, policies, and strategies into their 
national development plans. 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  Key activities under the TA are as follows: 
(i)  Create enabling DMC environments for increased investment in DSEE. ADB 
can add significant value in creating enabling national and regional strategic 
frameworks for DSEE policies, financing, and TA, as many DMC governments 
lack the capacity to do so. This output will build on existing knowledge about the 
role  of  governments  in  successful  DSEE  implementation.  Given  resource 
limitations, the TA has tentatively selected target DMCs, based on consultation 
with  operations  departments  and  a  broad  overall  assessment  of  institutional 
readiness,  existing  DSEE  commitments,  scale  of  opportunity,  and  the 
implementation  capacity  of  the  country  and  ADB.  The  first  stage  includes 
Indonesia, Kazakhstan, Mongolia, the Philippines, and Sri Lanka. The TA will 
remain  flexible  to  including  other  countries  with  identified  DSEE  potential, 
including Cambodia, Malaysia, Pakistan, Thailand, Viet Nam, and countries in 
the Pacific region, when new funding becomes available. Within the targeted 
DMCs, the programmatic themes identified for DSEE projects are (a) refurbishing 
public buildings and municipal lighting (e.g., street, public lighting, traffic lights); 
(b) retrofitting high energy intensity industries (e.g., cement, iron and steel, food 
processing, chemicals manufacturing, and mining); and (c) upgrading metering

systems for electric distribution utilities in preparation for a move toward smart 
grids. These themes have been selected based on available opportunity (size 
and number of sites), potential replicability, and relative ease of implementation. 
By  targeting  these  themes  and  working  with  country  stakeholders  and  ADB 
project teams, the TA will derive flagship initiatives and policy instruments.  
(ii)  Initiate  projects  that  can  be  replicated  to  scale-up  ADB  investment  in 
energy efficiency. DMCs need to access practical DSEE initiatives for which 
implementation assistance is available and that can be deployed at a sufficient 
scale to create a market for ADB investment. Under the TA, ADB will create 
technical  information  packages  on  how  to  implement  the  types  of  initiative 
targeted,  and  instigate  pilot  projects  to  enable  practical  knowledge  sharing. 
Potential  DSEE  opportunities  that  operations  departments  may  consider 
including among their DMC energy project investments will be assessed. The TA 
will focus strictly on DSEE outcomes rather than other aspects of efficiency (e.g., 
supply chain efficiencies, smart communities, and urban planning). Initiatives will 
be based on existing successful work that may be replicated, and may include (a) 
utility-sponsored DSEE resource programs, where ADB could facilitate demand-
side management and demand response programs for utilities to lead, and for 
which  utilities  would  receive  financial  incentives  and/or  TA;  (b)  direct 
development  support  for  local  financial  intermediaries,  i.e.,  direct  capacity 
creation and leverage for the role of local banks and energy services companies; 
and (c) DSEE interventions for end-users such as industry groups (e.g., through 
technology assistance), building owners (e.g., through incentive schemes), or 
household consumers (e.g., through labeling and information).  
(iii)  Strengthen  regional  DSEE  knowledge  networks  and  benchmarking 
information. An information system will underpin DSEE implementation capacity 
to support the case for DSEE investment. Data will be collected only for priority 
areas of the TA (e.g., energy supply and demand data and trends about selected 
countries, and energy intensity data for target sectors), and will be drawn from 
available national and global databases. Regional collaboration among DSEE 
organizations  and  practitioners  will  be  strengthened.  Knowledge  products 
emphasizing  South–South  cooperation,  best-practice  reviews  from  leading 
countries, and diagnostic reports on DSEE requirements and opportunities for 
target countries will be important to operations departments in their consultations 
with DMCs and in the development of DSEE project pipelines. 
11.  The risk that DMC governments would be unwilling to formulate and implement thematic 
DSEE programs, or to sustain their DSEE commitments, will be mitigated by the fact that target 
DMCs have stated priorities on climate action and/or energy efficiency and that DSEE is widely 
held as a first-option, least-cost productivity and greenhouse gas mitigation measure.  The TA 
itself will further raise DMC awareness and underscore DMC commitments to DSEE, through 
proposed  activities  that  link  country  stakeholder  groups  and  key  DMC  agencies  with 
international knowledge networks, NGOs, and other professional networks. 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $2,500,000, of which $2,000,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Multi-Donor Clean Energy Fund under the Clean Energy Financing Partnership

5
Facility,13 and $500,000 will be financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and 
Knowledge Partnership Fund, both administered by ADB. The cost estimates and financing plan 
are in Appendix 2. DMC governments will provide in-kind support. 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  The Regional and Sustainable Development Department, in coordination with ADB’s 
Energy Community of Practice and operations departments, will serve as the TA executing and 
implementing  agency.    The  ADB  Energy  Community  of  Practice  will  establish  an  energy 
efficiency  technical  support  team  (EETST)  with  a  small  core  of  technical  ADB  staff  and 
consultants as the key mechanism for implementation. EETST will have three main functions:  
(i)  Technical  support. The EETST will provide project development support to 
operations departments to enhance DSEE implementation, covering policy and 
regulation,  technology  transfer,  financing,  and  monitoring  and  evaluation. 
Operations departments will be able to access EETST staff to support their 
activities with DSEE components, including awareness raising, capacity building, 
and expert assistance for the design of loan packages. 
(ii)  Knowledge management. The EETST maintain a DSEE library that compiles 
an array of information related to DSEE, and monitor DSEE indicators and GHG 
inventories for DMCs (drawn mostly from existing sources).  
(iii)  Capacity  building  and  coordination.  The  EETST  will  coordinate  regional 
workshops and capacity-building activities that enhance DSEE implementation 
capacity in the region. 
14.  A total of 66 person-months of international consulting services and 72 person-months of 
national consulting services will be required, for specialized and/or country-specific expertise. 
The international consultants will be specialists in areas of energy policy, finance, industries and 
commercial  buildings,  information  analysis,  and  communications.    National  consultants  will 
provide support in energy audits, technologies, and monitoring and evaluation14 All procurement 
under the TA will be carried out in accordance with the ADB Procurement Guidelines (2013, as 
amended from time to time). Upon TA completion, all equipment procured under the TA will be 
turned over or disposed of in accordance with ADB’s project administration instruction.15 The TA 
will be implemented over 36 months from October 2013 to September 2016.  
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 
15.  The President recommends that the Board approve (i) ADB administering technical 
assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $2,000,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the 
Multi-Donor Clean Energy Fund under the Clean Energy Financing Partnership Facility, and (ii) 
ADB  administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $500,000  to  be 
financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund for 
the Asia Energy Efficiency Accelerator.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.  Introduction 
1.  The implementing project officer from the Sustainable Infrastructure Division of Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  will  serve  as  team  leader  to  coordinate  all  inputs  from  all 
consultants under the technical assistance (TA).   
 
B.  Scope of Work 
 
2.  The work includes (i) developing and documenting plans and policy initiatives and/or 
packages for demand-side energy efficiency (DSEE) investment for use in consultations with 
and for potential implementation by developing member countries (DMCs); (ii) performing 
stakeholder analysis, strategic assessments of DSEE status, building high-level consensus, 
and  securing  stakeholder  commitment  and  buy-in;  (iii)  building  capacity  on  DSEE 
implementation, including TA, knowledge management, network development, and training 
activities; (iv) documenting and making accessible information and data related to DSEE 
activity in the region; and (v) directly facilitating and assisting implementation of agreed DSEE 
operations plans by each selected DMC. 
 
C.  Terms of Reference 
 
3.  The consultants shall ensure that all work and outputs under this TA are fully compliant 
with ADB and government policies and guidelines.  
 
(i)  Energy  efficiency  policy  specialist  and  team  leader  (1  international 
consultant, 15 person-months). The team leader will be in charge of planning 
and implementing all activities, and will lead assistance in integrating DSEE into 
ongoing discussions with DMCs. All work will be done in collaboration with 
operations team members and national consultants. The team leader must hold 
postgraduate qualifications in economics, policy, or an energy-related field. The 
team leader will 
(a) lead  and  provide  information  and  analyses  toward  the  development  of 
policies and strategies for energy efficiency investment in DMCs, including 
preferred policy interventions for DMCs, in consultation with government 
agencies and resident missions; 
(b) identify  DSEE  stakeholders  and  key  proponents  in  selected  DMCs, 
undertake country capacity assessments, and commence engagement with 
a  view  to  developing  DSEE  investment  strategy  and  including  them  in 
country partnership strategies; 
(c) provide expert input to requests for regional TA that may be developed to 
create  high-level  policy  support  and  advance  investment  in  energy 
efficiency; 
(d) contribute  energy  efficiency  content  to  interdepartmental  energy  sector 
working groups; 
(e) represent ADB at DSEE events and seminars; and 
(f)  coordinate activities and provide guidance to other team members of the 
Energy Efficiency Technical Support Team (EETST), as required. 
 
(ii)  Energy  efficiency  finance  experts  (2  international  consultants,  5  person-
months  in  total).  The  experts  will  be  in  charge  of  TA  for  DSEE  financing,

Appendix 3  11 
providing an international best-practice perspective, and will work with national 
consultants and operations teams on implementation to ensure consistency 
with  the  overall  aims  of  the  TA.  The  experts  must  hold  postgraduate 
qualifications in economics, commerce, banking, or a related field. The experts 
will 
(a) provide information and analyses toward the development of best-practice 
initiatives for energy efficiency finance and investment in DMCs, including 
identified priority sectors, in consultation with government agencies and 
resident missions; 
(b) provide TA and advice to implementing agents in DMCs on DSEE finance 
opportunities  and  implementation  requirements,  including  elements  of 
successful projects and effective financing mechanisms; 
(c) provide expert input to requests for regional TA that may be developed to 
create investment programs and financial products for DSEE; 
(d) contribute  DSEE  content  to  interdepartmental  energy  sector  working 
groups; and 
(e) represent ADB at DSEE-related events and seminars. 
 
(iii)   Industrial energy efficiency project experts (5 international consultants, 10 
person-months in total). The experts will be in charge of TA for DSEE initiatives 
and project design for industrial facilities, and will work with national consultants 
and operations teams on implementation to ensure consistency with the overall 
aims  of  the  TA.  The  experts  must  hold  postgraduate  qualifications  in  an 
engineering- or energy-related field. The experts will 
(a) provide information and analyses toward the development of best-practice 
initiatives  for  energy  efficiency  investment  in  DMCs,  including  identified 
priority  sectors,  in  consultation  with  government  agencies  and  resident 
missions; 
(b) provide TA and advice to implementing agents in DMCs on industrial DSEE 
program design and implementation requirements, including elements of 
successful  projects,  selection  of  technologies,  effective  financing,  and 
monitoring and evaluation; 
(c) provide expert input to requests for regional TA that may be developed to 
create investment programs in DSEE for industrial sites; 
(d) contribute  DSEE  content  to  interdepartmental  energy  sector  working 
groups; and 
(e) represent ADB at DSEE-related events and seminars. 
 
(iv)  Commercial  building  energy  efficiency  project  experts  (5  international 
consultants, 10 person-months in total). The experts will be in charge of TA for 
DSEE  project  design  and  will  collaborate  with  national  consultants  and 
operations teams on their implementation. The experts must hold postgraduate 
qualifications in an engineering- or energy-related field. The experts will 
(a) provide information and analyses toward the development of best-practice 
initiatives for commercial building energy efficiency investment in DMCs, 
including  identified  priority  sectors,  in  consultation  with  government 
agencies and resident missions; 
(b) provide TA and advice to implementing agents in DMCs on DSEE program 
design and implementation requirements, including elements of successful 
projects, aspects of technology transfer, effective financing, and monitoring 
and evaluation;

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
(c) provide expert input to requests for regional TA that may be developed to 
create investment programs in DSEE; 
(d) contribute  DSEE  content  to  interdepartmental  energy  sector  working 
groups; and 
(e) represent ADB at DSEE-related events and seminars. 
 
(v)  Energy  efficiency  information  analysts  (2  international  consultants,  10 
person- months in total). The analysts will develop the information requirements 
and library of the EETST, including databases, statistics, and other information 
sources. The experts must hold postgraduate qualifications in an engineering-, 
information management-, or energy-related field. The analysts’ activities will 
include 
(a) building  the  platform  and  interface  for  a  regional  DSEE  database  that 
collates all DSEE functional data, including energy supply and demand 
data, market information, reports and articles, technology information, case 
studies, and stakeholder listings, for use internally and by DMCs in the 
design of DSEE projects and initiatives; 
(b) developing channels for dissemination of collated information and findings 
through both online delivery, establishment of a library service function for 
energy efficiency, and targeted awareness-raising campaigns; 
(c) assessing need for, and designing and executing publication of a regular 
regional report on the status of DSEE projects and progress toward the 
stated regional and DMC DSEE goals; 
(d) documenting instructions, and maintaining and updating a schedule for the 
DSEE library and database materials developed; and 
(e) contributing  to  the  content  of  DSEE  events,  seminars,  and 
interdepartmental working groups, as required. 
 
(vi)  Energy efficiency capacity and communications manager (2 international 
consultants, 16 person-months total). The managers will develop and maintain 
networks to strengthen knowledge exchange between energy efficiency 
practitioners, advocates, policy makers, and other stakeholders. They will also be 
responsible for the energy efficiency content of events and training programs to 
be run in support of the objectives of the EETST. The managers must hold 
qualifications in communications, marketing, or education, and should preferably 
have energy-related experience. The managers’ activities will include 
(a) identifying priority training needs for and designing and delivering training 
seminars, workshops, and events, in consultation with DMCs and internal 
ADB energy teams on DSEE-related issues; 
(b) establishing and maintaining a network of key knowledge-transfer agents 
across the region from all sectors, where possible facilitating links between 
like organizations to maximize learning and exchange; 
(c) leading  public  relations  for  work  completed  by  the  EETST,  including 
documenting  and  promoting  progress  and  success  stories,  organizing 
publicity events, and liaising with funding organizations on protocol; and 
(d) contributing  to  the  content  of  energy  efficiency  events,  seminars,  and 
interdepartmental working groups, as required. 
 
(vii)  Energy efficiency finance experts (5 national consultants, 10 person-months in 
total). The experts will work with national consultants and operations teams on 
implementation to ensure that financing models are effective and consistent with

Appendix 3  13 
the overall aims of the TA. The experts must hold postgraduate qualifications in 
economics, commerce, banking, or a related field. The experts’ activities will 
include 
(a) providing  information  and  analyses  toward  the  development  of  energy 
efficiency finance and investment in priority sectors within the DMC; 
(b) providing  TA  and  advice  to  implementing  agents  on  DSEE  finance 
opportunities and implementation requirements, including available effective 
financing mechanisms; 
(c) providing expert input to requests for regional TA that may be developed to 
create investment programs and financial products for DSEE; 
(d) contributing  DSEE  content  to  interdepartmental  energy  sector  working 
groups; and 
(e) representing ADB at DSEE-related events and seminars. 
 
(viii)  Energy efficiency auditors (5 national consultants, approximately 3.5 person-
months per DMC, 18 person-months total). The auditors will be based in target 
DMCs and will assist with ongoing implementation efforts. They will preferably 
have a strong knowledge of national DSEE policies and regulations, initiatives, 
stakeholders, and business finance, and will have experience of assessing 
energy efficiency opportunities in commercial buildings and industrial sites. The 
auditors  must  hold  postgraduate  qualifications  in  engineering,  as  well  as 
auditing accreditation in the country of operation. The auditors’ activities will 
include 
(a) performing site inspections and investment-grade energy audits to ascertain 
available energy efficiency opportunities at identified priority sites; 
(b) maintaining regular contact and liaison between DMC implementers and 
ADB to facilitate the investment process and report on issues promptly; 
(c) providing  local  businesses  with  advice,  and  assisting  them  with 
documentation requirements and loan processing; 
(d) documenting and reporting on the progress and status of projects according 
to ADB guidelines, including for publicity purposes; and 
(e) contributing  to  the  content  of  in-country  DSEE  events,  seminars,  and 
interdepartmental working groups, as required. 
 
(ix)  Energy efficiency technology experts (5 national consultants, approximately 
3.5 person-months per DMC, 18 person-months total).  The  experts will be 
based in targeted DMCs and will assist with ongoing implementation efforts. 
They will preferably have a strong knowledge of national DSEE policies and 
regulations,  initiatives,  stakeholders,  and  business  finance,  and  will  have 
experience of best-practice energy efficiency technology solutions and their 
application to available energy efficiency opportunities in commercial buildings 
and/or industrial sites. The experts must hold postgraduate qualifications in 
engineering or a field related to energy technology. The experts’ activities will 
include 
(a) specifying  and  coordinating  the  procurement  of  energy  efficiency 
technologies, taking into consideration energy efficiency opportunities at 
identified sites; 
(b) maintaining regular contact with and liaison between DMC implementers 
and  ADB  to  facilitate  the  investment  process  and  to  report  on  issues 
promptly;

14  Appendix 3 
 
 
(c) providing  local  businesses  with  advice,  and  assisting  them  with 
documentation requirements and loan processing; 
(d) documenting and reporting on the progress and status of projects according 
to ADB guidelines, including for publicity purposes; and 
(e) contributing  to  the  content  of  in-country  DSEE  events,  seminars,  and 
interdepartmental working groups, as required. 
 
(x)  Energy  efficiency  monitoring  and  evaluation  experts  (5  national 
consultants, approximately 5 person-months per DMC, 26 person-months total). 
The  experts  will  be  based  in  target  DMCs  and  will  assist  with  ongoing 
implementation efforts. They will preferably have a strong knowledge of national 
DSEE policies and regulations, initiatives, stakeholders, and business finance, 
and will have experience with energy efficiency data, energy metering and 
monitoring,  and  verification  and  reporting  regimes.  The  experts  must  hold 
postgraduate qualifications in engineering, and should preferably be accredited 
with a recognized monitoring and evaluation organization such as the Efficiency 
Valuation Organization. The experts’ activities will include 
(a) establishing monitoring and verification regimes for identified projects to 
underpin  investment  activity,  including  establishing  baseline  data  and 
arrangements for regular measuring of energy data; 
(b) maintaining regular contact with and liaison between DMC implementers 
and  ADB  to  facilitate  the  investment  process  and  to  report  on  issues 
promptly; 
(c) providing  local  businesses  with  advice,  and  assisting  them  with 
documentation requirements and loan processing; 
(d) documenting and reporting on the progress and status of projects according 
to ADB guidelines, especially in the provision of project data, including for 
publicity purposes; and 
(e) contributing  to  the  content  of  in-country  DSEE  events,  seminars,  and 
interdepartmental working groups, as required. 
 
D.   Reporting Requirements 
 
4.  The following reports will be submitted for each selected DMC at the key stages of TA 
implementation: 
(i)  inception  report  with  overall  work  plan  within  90  calendar  days  of  TA 
commencement; 
(ii)  midterm report containing the results of stakeholder assessments, developed 
DSEE initiatives and targeted countries, and results of training and plans for 
future events, within 9 calendar months of TA commencement; 
(iii)  implementation progress report 18 calendar months after TA commencement; and 
(iv)  final report 24 calendar months after TA commencement.
